statement.p:
Suppose that
\wvec_1=\threevec111,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\threevec1{-2}1.
Verify that \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 form an orthogonal basis for a plane W in \real^3.
Use to find \bhat, the orthogonal projection of \bvec=\threevec21{-1} onto W.
Find an orthonormal basis \uvec_1, \uvec_2 for W.
Find the matrix P representing the matrix transformation that projects vectors in \real^3 orthogonally onto W. Verify that \bhat = P\bvec.
Determine \rank(P) and explain its geometric significance.

Consider the vectors
\wvec_1=\threevec111,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\threevec{-1}01,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3=\threevec1{-2}1.
Explain why these vectors form an orthogonal basis for \real^3.
Suppose that A=\begin{bmatrix} \wvec_1 \amp \wvec_2 \amp \wvec_3 \end{bmatrix} and evaluate the product A^TA. Why is this product a diagonal matrix and what is the significance of the diagonal entries?
Express the vector \bvec=\threevec{-3}{-6}3 as a linear combination of \wvec_1, \wvec_2, and \wvec_3.
Multiply the vectors \wvec_1, \wvec_2, \wvec_3 by appropriate scalars to find an orthonormal basis \uvec_1, \uvec_2, \uvec_3 of \real^3.
If Q=\begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \amp \uvec_3 \end{bmatrix}, find the matrix product QQ^T and explain the result.

Suppose that
\wvec_1=\fourvec110{-1}, \hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\fourvec1011
form an orthogonal basis for a subspace W of \real^4.
Find \bhat, the orthogonal projection of \bvec=\fourvec{2}{-1}{-6}{7} onto W.
Find the vector \bvec^\perp in W^\perp such that \bvec = \bhat + \bvec^\perp.
Find a basis for W^\perp. and express \bvec^\perp as a linear combination of the basis vectors.

Consider the vectors
\wvec_1=\fourvec1100,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\fourvec0011,\hspace{24pt} \bvec=\fourvec2{-4}13.
If L is the line defined by the vector \wvec_1, find the vector in L closest to \bvec. Call this vector \bhat_1.
If W is the subspace spanned by \wvec_1 and \wvec_2, find the vector in W closest to \bvec. Call this vector \bhat_2.
Determine whether \bhat_1 or \bhat_2 is closer to \bvec and explain why.

Suppose that \wvec=\threevec2{-1}2 defines a line L in \real^3.
Find the orthogonal projections of the vectors \threevec100, \threevec010, \threevec001 onto L.
Find the matrix P = \frac{1}{\len{\wvec}^2} \wvec \wvec^T.
Use to explain why the columns of P are related to the orthogonal projections you found in the first part of this exericse.
Explain the relationship between the line L and the column space \col(P).

Suppose that
\vvec_1=\threevec103,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec222
form the basis for a plane P in \real^3.
Find a basis for the line that is the orthogonal complement P^\perp.
Given the vector \bvec=\threevec6{-6}2, find \yvec, the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto the line P^\perp.
Explain why the vector \zvec = \bvec-\yvec must be in W and write \zvec as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.

Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your thinking.
If the columns of Q form an orthonormal basis for a subspace W and \wvec is a vector in W, then QQ^T\wvec = \wvec.
An orthogonal set of vectors in \real^8 can have no more than 8 vectors.
If Q is a 7\times5 matrix whose columns are orthonormal, then QQ^T = I_7.
If Q is a 7\times5 matrix whose columns are orthonormal, then Q^TQ = I_5.
Suppose that the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto a subspace W satisfies \bhat = \zerovec. Then \bvec is in W^\perp.

Suppose that Q is an orthogonal matrix.
Remembering that \vvec\cdot\wvec=\vvec^T\wvec, explain why
Q\xvec\cdot(Q\yvec) = \xvec\cdot\yvec.
Explain why \len{Q\xvec} = \len{\xvec}.
This means that the length of a vector is unchanged after multiplying by an orthogonal matrix.
If \lambda is a real eigenvalue of Q, explain why \lambda=\pm1.

Explain why the following statements are true.
If Q is an orthogonal matrix, then \det Q = \pm 1.
If Q is a 8\times 4 matrix whose columns are orthonormal, then QQ^T is an 8\times8 matrix whose rank is 4.
If \bhat is the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto a subspace W, then \bvec-\bhat is the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W^\perp.

This exercise is about 2\times2 orthogonal matrices.
In , we saw that the matrix \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \end{bmatrix}
represents a rotation by an angle \theta. Explain why this matrix is an orthogonal matrix.
We also saw that the matrix \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta \amp \sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp -\cos\theta \end{bmatrix}
represents a reflection in a line. Explain why this matrix is an orthogonal matrix.
Suppose that \uvec_1=\twovec{\cos\theta}{\sin\theta} is a 2-dimensional unit vector. Use a sketch to indicate all the possible vectors \uvec_2 such that \uvec_1 and \uvec_2 form an orthonormal basis of \real^2.
Explain why every 2\times2 orthogonal matrix is either a rotation or a reflection.
